+1, I think taking some MechE specific classes will help tremendously.
It sounds like MechE is your true passion, and CS is more of your interest. If so, just do what you are really passionate about, at least you will be happier that way.

history.content:
I'm a MechE currently finishing up my second semester here at Berkeley. I'm considering a switch into EECS, but I'm not entirely sure if I will or should. To give some background, here are some things that I like about both fields.

Reasons that CS is appealing:

  • I really like the math-y side of things (space and runtime analysis, figuring out more efficient ways of doing things)
  • I already feel like I have a good grasp of what "computer scientists" do in the real world, whereas I don't really know what mechanical engineers do.
    • I feel like 61A and 61B have given me a decent perspective of what CS is like, although I don't actually know if this is true. I can't say the same for MechE because I haven't even taken a single ME-specific class.
  • Berkeley is in a great location to pursue CS, and graduates make tons of $$$.

 

Reasons that MechE is appealing:

  • It's what I applied here to do, and it's what I've envisioned myself doing for a pretty long time. I'm fascinated by things that fly, and I still want to work in that field.
  • I would not starve as a mechanical engineer. (In fact, I would still live quite comfortably). 
  • I want to work in a field with more social impact. I'm really drawn to the idea of working at somewhere like NASA, where I'd be in the public sector and I'd feel like I'm effecting more change in the world.
    • I don't know if this is actually true. Obviously, computers have changed our lives in *huge* ways, too.
      • I might just be drawn to the fact that it seems like mechanical engineers already know what "big problems" they need to solve (e.g. we want to go to Mars! we want to make renewable energy!), whereas CS seems more entrepreneurial and concerned with making things like food delivery apps or something.
  • There are a ton of CS majors, so being MechE is cool and unsquare. Also, it might be the case that there will be too many CS majors entering the job market in the future(?).
  • I can still use computer programming if I work in MechE.

 

Anyways, I hope that some of you can provide me with some more guidance or advice. I've asked a MechE professor about this, and what he said essentially boiled down to "both fields use computer programming, but for different applications" (which is cool because I like to program). I guess that my questions are, "What would differentiate applications of CS from applications of MechE? What kind of job market would I be looking at for both fields? Where could I make the most (positive) impact on our lives?" 

 

Thanks!

 

Note: Would minoring or double-majoring (lol) in EECS allay any of these concerns?

*reposted from 61B piazza*
